title: UCI Gravel World Championships 2023 race galleries: Almost a roaring success
content:
Cyclist
UCI Gravel World Championships 2023 race galleries: Almost a roaring success

The second ever UCI Gravel World Championships took place this weekend in Treviso, Italy with racers from across the disciplines all gunning for one title. After heavy criticism of the first edition, this year’s took on a new route and it seemed to have gone down well. Proper gravel with lots of proper gravel racers among a host of the WorldTour’s best riders as well as qualifiers from the Gravel World Series races.

It wasn’t all sunshine and smiles, although it looked like it. There was no TV coverage for the elite women’s race, which just isn’t good enough. The UCI has decreed it ‘mandatory’ from next year onwards though, which makes you think, why wasn’t it already? Everyone loved watching every discipline under the sun in Glasgow this summer, why was this event the only one you couldn’t see?

Anyway, television’s loss is our gain because our man on the ground James York was there taking photos of both the elite races (as well as tech-spotting), so here are our highlights from the women’s and men’s races.

Women’s race gallery: What THEY don’t want you to see

The calm before the chaos.

The top seeds lined up at the front in good spirits, maybe it was the gravel party atmosphere, maybe it was defending champion Pauline Ferrand-Prévot dropping out with Covid.

The race went straight into a hill to get the heart rate going.

Cyclocross vibes.

Vineyards were strategically placed alongside the race to remind the riders what’s waiting for them on the podium.

Demi Vollering is so good she can do it with her eyes closed.

The best placed American finisher on the day was EF Education-TIBCO-SVB’s Lauren Stephens in a strong sixth, four minutes down on the eventual winner.

The best British finisher was Annabel Fisher who fought through a broken derailleur with 20km to go to finish in 20th, ten minutes down.

It’s not Strade Bianche, but it is strade bianche. Things are getting very selective at this point, this is the front of the race.

Australia’s Tiffany Cromwell and Argentina’s Sofia Gomez Villafañe – who has been the best pro gravel racer this year – fighting to get back on.

Italy’s cyclocross star Silvia Persico putting the pressure on on the hills ahead of Stephens, Lorena Wiebes, Simone Boilard, Yara Kastelijn, Kasia Niewiadoma, Demi Vollering and Gaia Realini.

Niamh Fisher-Black was in among the front group too and looks in the zone.

It was a tough day out for Gomez Villafañe, who said she didn’t have the legs on the day and posted on Instagram, ‘Learned a lot and have a lot of think about on how to move forward. The truth is that European Gravel is very different than American Gravel for women and my legs just were not ready for the constant VO2 efforts that the ladies were throwing down. I hung on for as long as I could and chase back a few times but it all added up and I was just empty. On the second loop I also made a decision to follow the rules and to not jump on the train of men that a lot of ladies found themselves in and kept it steady to the finish.’

Kasia Niewiadoma eventually pushed clear on one of the steep climbs and held on to finish solo, 33 seconds clear of Silvia Persico and Demi Vollering who sprinted for second.

After a fantastic performance at the Tour de France this year, a rainbow jersey is a fitting end to the year for fan-favourite Niewiadoma.

No road bikes on display this year. Wonder what that one is.

Hopefully Fisher will be spurred on with her good result, she wasn’t far back at all especially considering the issues she faced.

It might be cycling’s newest discipline but rainbows are rainbows and that one means a lot. Would’ve been awesome to watch, let’s do it all again next year.

It’s off-season time. Well deserved. And a big pat on the back to whoever predicted that podium.

Men’s race gallery: Is this Paris-Roubaix?

In case there was any doubt, this is Italy.

Wout van Aert: ‘It’s just a big cyclocross race, right?’ Cameron Mason: ‘I think you may be in for a shock.’

Lovely setting for a bike race.

Lovely setting to watch a bike race.

Matej Mohorič and Florian Vermeersch got to the front early and put the pressure on. Despite starting quite a way back, dominant American gravel pro Keegan Swenson was quickly among the leaders.

Mason was Britain’s highest seed and described it as ‘the highest level racing’ he’s done in his career and came home a very respectable 24th.

This way to the Prosecco.

Swenson was caught up in a crash but was among the main fight all day.

Second best American was Alexey Vermeulen (right), who finished 21 minutes down in 33rd.

The front of the race looked eerily similar to a Paris-Roubaix breakaway: Florian Vermeersch, Matej Mohorič and Connor Swift.

Chasing behind was Alejandro Valverde, Alessandro De Marchi, Paul Voss and Swenson.

But they couldn’t reel in this trio, who worked hard and held on.

Meanwhile, pre-race favourite Wout van Aert was caught up in crashes and mechanicals, finding himself over 100 places and ten minutes back but fought hard the whole race to make it back to a ridiculously impressive eighth.

The second group were joined by Quinten Hermans (right) and Sebastian Schönberger (orange helmet) for a bit, but Schönberger was caught and passed by Van Aert by the finish.

Defending champion Gianni Vermeersch came home 11th, almost 11 minutes down.

Third placed British rider was Dolan-Elesse’s Sam Culverwell in 40th, he ended up four places behind Ireland’s top man Nicolas Roche (right).

And it was another fan favourite Matej Mohorič who broke clear from Vermeersch with Swift already dropped, he finished 43 seconds ahead.

Everyone loves Mohorič – you can find out more about him in our profile ‘Pursuit of Perfection’.

Belgian media outlet Sporza shared a picture of Van Aert’s Garmin, which showed his moving time to be less than Mohorič’s finish time. A very strong ride but, like Paris-Roubaix this year, part of the race is about staying upright and riding your luck. Van Aert himself certainly wouldn’t diminish Mohorič’s efforts.

That is a podium that affirms the UCI’s decision to take gravel on, big talents. Paris-Roubaix runner-up, winner of Milan-San Remo, winner of Tro-Bro-Léon (among many many other results). It all translates.

We can all agree you’d struggle to pick a more deserving winner in 2023.

Cheers.

author: Will Strickson | Deputy Website Editor
